moves: 1. Nf3 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. c4 Bf5 4. Nc3
comment:
(The traditional plan is 4...Nbd7 and 5..
.e5. The critical test of the move played is probably 5.Bg5 Be7 6.Qb3)

moves: 1. Nf3 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. c4 Bf5 4. Nc3 e6 5. g3 Ne4 6. Bd2 Be7 7. Bg2 Nd7 8. O-O c5 9. d5 Qb6 10. b3 O-O
comment:
#(At this point
, not having achieved very much in the opening, I decided on radical action to
seize the initiative, Remember Fischer's 1...Nh5 against Spassky?)

moves: 1. Nf3 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. c4 Bf5 4. Nc3 e6 5. g3 Ne4 6. Bd2 Be7 7. Bg2 Nd7 8. O-O c5 9. d5 Qb6 10. b3 O-O 11. Nh4 Nxd2 12. Qxd2 Bxh4 13. gxh4 e5 14. Qg5 Bg6 15. h5 f6 16. Qh4 Be8 17. e4 Qd8 18. Bh3 f5
comment:
(Black must play this to avoid strangulation, but it might have been
tried a move earlier.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. c4 Bf5 4. Nc3 e6 5. g3 Ne4 6. Bd2 Be7 7. Bg2 Nd7 8. O-O c5 9. d5 Qb6 10. b3 O-O 11. Nh4 Nxd2 12. Qxd2 Bxh4 13. gxh4 e5 14. Qg5 Bg6 15. h5 f6 16. Qh4 Be8 17. e4 Qd8 18. Bh3 f5 19. Qxd8 Rxd8 20. Bxf5 Bxh5 21. Nb5 Nf6 22. f4
comment:
(Around here I began to feel optimistic: White aims to create a central passed
pawn.)#

White's strategy, optimism grew into confidence.)
